title: Everyday Life in Ancient Israel
html: EVERYDAY LIFE IN ANCIENT ISRAELWHAT was everyday life like back in Bible times? What sort of homes did ordinary people have? What kinds of work did they do? What were their customs? Your having some knowledge of these things can aid you in visualizing Bible accounts. At times, that background information is also the key to understanding the meaning of scriptures.[Picture on page 952]Most houses, like this one in Jerusalem, had flat roofs on which people might visit, walk in the cool evening, or even sleep (Lu 17:31)[Picture on page 952]Ancient lamps, made of earthenware, in which oil was burned (Mt 25:1-4)[Picture on page 952]A household oven of the sort that was common among the Israelites (Le 26:26)[Picture on page 952]Hebrew men and women often carried loads on their shoulder (Ge 24:15; Nu 7:9)[Picture on page 952]Vessels were of many sizes and shapes, usually earthenware, sometimes made of stone (1Ki 17:12)[Picture on page 953]Threshing, sometimes done with the hooves of animals, separated grain from the chaff (1Ti 5:18)[Picture on page 953]Winnowing involved tossing the grain so that the wind would carry away the chaff (Jer 51:2)[Picture on page 953]A millstone that was likely used to crush olives so that the oil could be extracted (Nu 18:27)[Picture on page 953]Hand mill, used to grind grain into flour (Mt 24:41)[Picture on page 954]Sheepherding was a common occupation in Bible times (Lu 15:4)[Picture on page 954]Donkeys, or asses, were frequently used as beasts of burden (1Ch 12:40)[Picture on page 954]Wells were, and still are, a common source of water in this land (Ge 29:10)
